item.text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he ruled in Jerusalem for 11 years. His mother’s name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah.
He did what displeased the Lord just as Jehoiakim had done.
What follows is a record of what happened to Jerusalem and Judah because of the Lord’s anger when he drove them out of his sight. Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.

<st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="05019" class="">Nebuchadnezzar</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">came</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">against</st> <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st> with his <st data-num="03605" class="">whole</st> <st data-num="02428" class="">army</st> and <st data-num="02583" class="">set up camp</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">outside</st> it.<n id="1" /> They <st data-num="01129" class="">built</st> <st data-num="01785" class="">siege ramps</st> <st data-num="05921 05439">all around</st> it. He <st data-num="01961" class="">arrived</st> on the <st data-num="06218" class="">tenth</st> <st data-num="02320" class="">day</st> of the <st data-num="06224" class="">tenth</st> <st data-num="02320" class="">month</st> in the <st data-num="08671" class="">ninth</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">year</st> that Zedekiah <st data-num="04427" class="">ruled</st> over Judah.<n id="2" />

The <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">remained</st> under <st data-num="04692" class="">siege</st> <st data-num="05704" class="">until</st> <st data-num="04428 06667">Zedekiah’s</st> <st data-num="06249 06240">eleventh</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">year</st>.

By the <st data-num="08672" class="">ninth</st> <st data-num="02320" class="">day</st> of the <st data-num="07243" class="">fourth</st> <st data-num="02320" class="">month</st><n id="1" /> the <st data-num="07458" class="">famine</st> in the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st> <st data-num="02388" class="">was</st> so <st data-num="02388" class="">severe</st> the <st data-num="05971 0776">residents</st><n id="2" /> <st data-num="01961" class="">had</st> <st data-num="03808" class="">no</st> <st data-num="03899" class="">food</st>.

They <st data-num="01234" class="">broke through</st> the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st> walls, and <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="0376 04421">soldiers</st> tried to <st data-num="01272" class="">escape</st>. They <st data-num="03318" class="">left</st> the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st> during the <st data-num="03915" class="">night</st>. They went <st data-num="01870" class="">through</st> the <st data-num="08179" class="">gate</st> <st data-num="0996" class="">between</st> the two <st data-num="02346" class="">walls</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">that</st> is <st data-num="05921" class="">near</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king’s</st> <st data-num="01588" class="">garden</st>.<n id="1" /> (The <st data-num="03778" class="">Babylonians</st> had the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st> <st data-num="05921 05439">surrounded</st>.) Then they <st data-num="01980" class="">headed</st> <st data-num="01870" class="">for</st> the <st data-num="06160" class="">rift valley</st>.<n id="2" />

But the <st data-num="03778" class="">Babylonian</st> <st data-num="02428" class="">army</st> <st data-num="07291" class="">chased</st> <st data-num="0310" class="">after</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st>. They <st data-num="05381" class="">caught up with</st> <st data-num="06667" class="">Zedekiah</st> in the <st data-num="06160" class="">plains</st><n id="1" /> of <st data-num="03405" class="">Jericho</st>,<n id="2" /> and his <st data-num="03605" class="">entire</st> <st data-num="02428" class="">army</st> <st data-num="06327 05921">deserted</st> him.

They <st data-num="08610" class="">captured</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">him</st> and <st data-num="05927" class="">brought</st> him <st data-num="05927" class="">up</st> <st data-num="0413" class="">to</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st> at <st data-num="07247" class="">Riblah</st><n id="1" /> in the <st data-num="0776" class="">territory</st> of <st data-num="02574" class="">Hamath</st>, and he <st data-num="01696" class="">passed</st> <st data-num="04941" class="">sentence</st> <st data-num="0854" class="">on</st> him there.

The <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st> had <st data-num="06667" class="">Zedekiah’s</st> <st data-num="01121" class="">sons</st> <st data-num="07819" class="">put to death</st> while Zedekiah was forced to <st data-num="05869" class="">watch</st>. He <st data-num="01571" class="">also</st> had <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="08269" class="">nobles</st> of <st data-num="03063" class="">Judah</st> <st data-num="07819" class="">put to death</st> there at <st data-num="07247" class="">Riblah</st>.
He had Zedekiah’s eyes put out and had him bound in chains. Then the king of Babylon had him led off to Babylon, and he was imprisoned there until the day he died.
On the tenth day of the fifth month, in the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, Nebuzaradan, the captain of the royal guard who served the king of Babylon, arrived in Jerusalem.
He burned down the Lord’s temple, the royal palace, and all the houses in Jerusalem, including every large house.

The <st data-num="03605" class="">whole</st> <st data-num="03778" class="">Babylonian</st> <st data-num="02428" class="">army</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">that</st> came <st data-num="0854" class="">with</st> the <st data-num="07227" class="">captain</st> of the <st data-num="02876" class="">royal guard</st> <st data-num="05422" class="">tore down</st> <st data-num="03605" class="">the</st> <st data-num="02346" class="">walls</st> that <st data-num="05439" class="">surrounded</st> <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st>.

<st data-num="05018" class="">Nebuzaradan</st>, the <st data-num="07227" class="">captain</st> of the <st data-num="02876" class="">royal guard</st>, <st data-num="01540" class="">took into exile</st> some of the <st data-num="01803 05971">poor</st>,<n id="1" /> the <st data-num="03499" class="">rest</st> of the <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> who <st data-num="07604" class="">remained</st> in the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st>, <st data-num="05307" class="">those</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">who</st> had <st data-num="05307" class="">deserted</st> <st data-num="0413" class="">to</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st>, and the <st data-num="03499" class="">rest</st> of the <st data-num="0527" class="">craftsmen</st>.
But he left behind some of the poor and gave them fields and vineyards.
The Babylonians broke the two bronze pillars in the temple of the Lord, as well as the movable stands and the large bronze basin called “The Sea.” They took all the bronze to Babylon.

They also <st data-num="03947" class="">took</st> the <st data-num="05518" class="">pots</st>, <st data-num="03257" class="">shovels</st>,<n id="1" /> <st data-num="04212" class="">trimming shears</st>,<n id="2" /> <st data-num="04219" class="">basins</st>, <st data-num="03709" class="">pans</st>, and <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="05178" class="">bronze</st> <st data-num="03627 0834">utensils</st> <st data-num="08334" class="">used</st> by the priests.<n id="3" />

The <st data-num="07227" class="">captain</st> of the <st data-num="02876" class="">royal guard</st> <st data-num="03947" class="">took</st> the <st data-num="0834 02091 02091">gold</st> and <st data-num="0834 03701 03701">silver</st> <st data-num="05592" class="">bowls</st>, <st data-num="04289" class="">censers</st>,<n id="1" /> <st data-num="04219" class="">basins</st>, <st data-num="05518" class="">pots</st>, <st data-num="04501" class="">lampstands</st>, <st data-num="03709" class="">pans</st>, and <st data-num="04518" class="">vessels</st>.<n id="2" />

The bronze of the items that King Solomon made for the Lord’s temple (including the two pillars, the large bronze basin called “The Sea,” the 12 bronze bulls under “The Sea,” and the movable stands) was too heavy to be weighed.

<st data-num="05982 0259">Each</st> of the <st data-num="05982" class="">pillars</st> was about <st data-num="08083 06240">27</st> <st data-num="0520" class="">feet</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="06967" class="">high</st>, about <st data-num="08147 06240">18</st> <st data-num="0520" class="">feet</st><n id="2" /> in <st data-num="02339 05437">circumference</st>, <st data-num="0702" class="">three</st> <st data-num="0676" class="">inches</st><n id="3" /> <st data-num="05672" class="">thick</st>, and <st data-num="05014" class="">hollow</st>.

The <st data-num="05178" class="">bronze</st> <st data-num="03805" class="">top</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">of</st> <st data-num="0259" class="">one</st> pillar was about <st data-num="02568" class="">7½</st> <st data-num="0520" class="">feet</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="06967" class="">high</st> and had <st data-num="05178" class="">bronze</st> <st data-num="07639" class="">latticework</st> and <st data-num="07416" class="">pomegranate-shaped ornaments</st> <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> <st data-num="05921 05439">around</st> <st data-num="03805" class="">it</st>. The <st data-num="08145" class="">second</st> <st data-num="05982" class="">pillar</st> with its <st data-num="07416" class="">pomegranate-shaped ornaments</st> was like <st data-num="0428" class="">it</st>.
There were 96 pomegranate-shaped ornaments on the sides; in all there were 100 pomegranate-shaped ornaments over the latticework that went around it.
The captain of the royal guard took Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the priest who was second in rank, and the three doorkeepers.

<st data-num="04480" class="">From</st> the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st> he <st data-num="03947" class="">took</st> <st data-num="0259" class="">an</st> <st data-num="05631" class="">official</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">who</st> <st data-num="01961" class="">was</st> <st data-num="06496" class="">in charge</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">of</st> the <st data-num="0582 04421">soldiers</st>, <st data-num="07651 0582">seven</st> of the <st data-num="04428" class="">king’s</st> <st data-num="07200 06440">advisers</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">who</st> were <st data-num="04672" class="">discovered</st> in the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st>, an <st data-num="08269" class="">official</st> <st data-num="06635" class="">army</st> <st data-num="05608" class="">secretary</st> who <st data-num="06633" class="">drafted</st> <st data-num="05971 0776">citizens</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="06633" class="">for military service</st>, and <st data-num="08346" class="">60</st> <st data-num="0376 05971 0776">citizens</st> who were <st data-num="04672" class="">discovered</st> in the <st data-num="08432" class="">middle</st> of the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st>.

<st data-num="05018" class="">Nebuzaradan</st>, the <st data-num="07227" class="">captain</st> of the <st data-num="02876" class="">royal guard</st>, <st data-num="03947" class="">took</st> them and <st data-num="01980" class="">brought</st> them <st data-num="0413" class="">to</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st> at <st data-num="07247" class="">Riblah</st>.

The king of Babylon ordered them to be executed at Riblah in the territory of Hamath.

So Judah was taken into exile away from its land.

<st data-num="02088" class="">Here</st> is the official record of the number of <st data-num="05971 0834">people</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="05019" class="">Nebuchadnezzar</st> <st data-num="01540" class="">carried into exile</st>: In the <st data-num="07651" class="">seventh</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">year</st>,<n id="2" /> <st data-num="07969 0505 06242 07969">3,023</st> <st data-num="03064">Jews</st>;

in <st data-num="05019" class="">Nebuchadnezzar’s</st> <st data-num="08083 06240">eighteenth</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">year</st>,<n id="1" /> <st data-num="08083 03967 07970 08147">832</st> <st data-num="05315" class="">people</st> from <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st>;
in Nebuchadnezzar’s twenty-third year, Nebuzaradan, the captain of the royal guard, carried into exile 745 Judeans. In all, 4,600 people went into exile.

In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of King Jehoiachin of Judah, on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, King Evil Merodach of Babylon, in the first year of his reign, pardoned King Jehoiachin of Judah and released him from prison.

He <st data-num="01696" class="">spoke</st> <st data-num="02896" class="">kindly</st> to him and <st data-num="05414" class="">gave</st> <st data-num="03678" class="">him</st> a more <st data-num="04605" class="">prestigious</st> <st data-num="03678" class="">position</st> than<n id="1" /> the other <st data-num="04428" class="">kings</st> <st data-num="0834" class="">who</st> were <st data-num="0854" class="">with</st> him in <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st>.

Jehoiachin<n id="1" /> <st data-num="08138" class="">took off</st> his <st data-num="03608" class="">prison</st> <st data-num="0899" class="">clothes</st> and <st data-num="0398 03899">ate</st> <st data-num="08548" class="">daily</st> in the king’s <st data-num="06440" class="">presence</st> for the <st data-num="03605 03117">rest</st> of his <st data-num="02416" class="">life</st>.
He was given daily provisions by the king of Babylon for the rest of his life until the day he died.
